qas.question: Among what twentieth century scientists was idealism popular?
Along with quantum physics generally, what scientific doctrine caused some physicists to embrace idealism?
In what year was the second edition of The Grammar of Science published?
What did Pearson claim that science classifies?
Who is claimed to have been influenced by The Grammar of Science?
When did idealism fall out of practice?
What did the theory of relativity first appear in?
When did Einstein publish The Grammar of Science?

plausible_answers.text: a classification and analysis of the contents of the mind

qas.question: What did Einstein say science is?

context: Idealist notions took a strong hold among <a0_0>physicists<a0_0/> of <b5_0>the early 20th century<b5_0/> confronted with the paradoxes of quantum physics and the theory of <a1_0>relativity<a1_0/>. In <b6_0>The Grammar of Science<b6_0/>, Preface to the 2nd Edition, <a2_0><b7_0>1900<b7_0/><a2_0/>, <b8_0>Karl Pearson<b8_0/> wrote, "There are many signs that a sound idealism is surely replacing, as a basis for natural philosophy, the crude materialism of the older physicists." This book influenced <a4_0>Einstein<a4_0/>'s regard for the importance of the observer in scientific measurements[citation needed]. In § 5 of that book, Pearson asserted that "...science is in reality <b9_0>a classification and analysis of the <a3_0>contents of the mind<b9_0/><a3_0/>...." Also, "...the field of science is much more consciousness than an external world."
